title: Business groups warn against fresh Brexit delays
text:
“An extension helps avoid ‘no deal’ but, in reality, it also prolongs the agony and uncertainty,” said Stephen Phipson, chief executive of Make UK, the manufacturers’ organisation.

“It’s costing money, holding up investment and stalling order flow from [the EU]. It is now vital that we do not waste this extension as we want to get a good [Brexit] deal done.”

Josh Hardie, CBI deputy director-general, said: “Uncertainty remains high. It is vital — this time — the extra time leads to a deal.”

Adam Marshall, director-general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said companies will be “relieved that the immediate threat of a messy and disorderly departure has been avoided this week, and frustrated that they still do not have a permanent solution that allows them to invest, trade and plan for the future”.

A survey by the BCC found that almost half of internationally active UK businesses considered Brexit uncertainty a barrier to exports.

Ian Wright, chief executive of the Food and Drink Federation, pointed to “an underlying sense of frustration and anger” at “costly, wasted preparations” for a no-deal Brexit.

“The timescale ahead is challenging,” he added. “It is critical that we do not find ourselves, in January, once again facing the precipice, having spent millions of pounds preparing for a no-deal exit three times in the past 12 months.”

Nimisha Raja, founder of Nim’s Fruit Crisps, a snack manufacturer based in Sittingbourne, Kent, said she has put on hold any type of export contract to mainland Europe because of Brexit uncertainty.

Advertisement

She added that unlike in the run-up to the March 29 Brexit deadline, she had not stockpiled ingredients ahead of October 31. “I am just fed up with it all,” she said.

Business lobby groups are pressing the government to provide greater clarity not just over the withdrawal agreement but also the UK’s long term trading relationship with the EU.

Groups had been planning to use this week to talk to the government about the next Budget, which the Treasury shelved last week having previously scheduled it for November 6.

The head of a smaller British retailer said the uncertainty engendered by the latest Brexit delay “was not good for business at all”, adding the high street would also be hurt by an election ahead of Christmas.

“The last thing we want is an election in December,” he added. “It just distracts everyone. Historically, elections have not been good for retailers, they really slow consumers down and trading is very challenging already.”

Gary Grant, founder of the Entertainer, a chain of toy stores, agreed an election would be unwelcome. “I’m probably as confused as everyone else [by Brexit] . . . as a business leader I need to know what I’m planning for,” he said. “I’d rather delay than leave with a bad deal.”

Financial Times
description: Companies have responded to the uncertainty by holding off on investment plans, and manufacturers notably have stockpiled components for fear of border disruption in a no-deal Brexit
